RANsquawk Central Bank Weekly Briefing, 8 June 2018
content:
• To download the full report, please click here
  • FED: 25bps hike expected; watch forecasts – will there be a fourth dot in 2018
  • ECB: To discuss an exit from QE
  • BOJ: Move on, nothing to see here
  • SNB: Sovereign Money Initiative unlikely to pass
  • CBT: Turkey’s central bank continues to build inflation credibility ahead of elections
  • RBI: Is now firmly shifting focus on inflation
  • BCB: Ramping up aggression of FX interventions
  • TRIPLE-HEADER: Back-to-back meetings from tier one central banks next week will dictate the tone for global markets. And with the FOMC and ECB tilting towards tighter policy, further pressure could be heaped on EM central banks, many of which are already taking action to stabilise thier currencies in order to get a grip of domestic price pressures. It is worth noting that the weakness in FX of some major EMs has also been driven by idiosyncratic factors (politics/elections in the case of TRY, BRL and MXN, as well as trade negotiations for the latter), but to what extent will the Fed/ECB moving towards normalisation hit the EM complex? Capital Economics suggest that fears that a reduction in the size of the Fed's balance sheet will reduce the amount of dollars available to EMs to finance their external liabilities may be too simplistic; instead it argues that a rise in US rates will cause problems for the handful of EMs with large external financing needs, but for most the macro effect of higher US interest rates will be limited, arguing that the likes of Turkey, Argentina, and to a lesser extent south Africa will be in the crossairs. CapEco says "the best way to the think about how higher US rates will affect emerging economies is through the prism of EM balance sheets," adding that "the key point is that external financing requirements (and thus dollar funding needs) are generally lower now than in previous tightening cycles – current account deficits are smaller and FX debt burdens have eased."

subject: US Market Wrap - 8th June 2018: Trump splits G7 ahead of NK summit
content:
To download the report, please click here

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries flat , DXY higher, Crude lower
  • * REAR-VIEW: G6+1 unlikely to release communique; Canada labour report soft, but wages encouraging; Barnier cool on backstop proposal, ongoing discussion
  • * NEXT WEEK/WEEKEND: G7; NK summit; FOMC; ECB; BOJ; Brexit vote; bits of tier one data

 

* G7 SUMMIT: Failure to advance progress in resolving trade tensions has resulted in a lack of consensus among the G7, and it remains ‘highly unlikely’ that there will be a joint statement from members, a view shared by German Chancellor Merkel. There were areas of contention outside trade; US President Trump’s suggestion that Russia should once again be permitted to rejoin the G7 was rebuffed by most members, with the exception of Italy. Meetings with Trump have taken place, though the US President will leave early in order to prepare for his summit with NK leader Kim on Tuesday.

* BREXIT: EU chief Brexit negotiator Barnier welcomed the UK customs paper, but was cool on the UK's backstop proposal (note, some wires reported that the deal was "rejected", forcing Barnier to issue a tweet clarifying his stance that he was not rejecting it, it was still in discussions), and stated that it cannot be extended to the whole of the UK. Specifically, Barnier said that the proposals cannot qualify since they do not address regulatory alignment. Barnier also urged that a solution to the Irish issue is needed by the autumn. Barnier did say, however, that he was prepared to increase the pace and intensity of negotiations with the UK. UK PM May, responding to Barnier, said she will have to talk over the backstop proposal with EU negotiators. Later it was reported that UK government was considering keeping EU rules for Northern Ireland in the backstop proposal, however, this has not been decided at minister level. Elsewhere, UK Chancellor Hammond said the notion that the UK would rejoin the EU was 'fanciful', reiterating the case that the UK wants a bespoke partnership with the EU. Meanwhile, the German finance minister Scholz said that there was no guarantee that a Brexit deal can be reached, businesses must be prepared for every scenario.

* DATA: Canadian labour market data showed a loss of 7.5k jobs in May, missing the expected increase of 17.5k. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 5.8%, as expected, while the participation rate nudged lower to 65.3% from 65.4%. The fall in jobs saw a steeper decline than in April, when jobs fell by only 1,000; the trend is being blamed on bad weather. Focus nonetheless fell on wages, which are now growing at a 3.9% YY, the quickest rate since 2012, vastly outpacing the pace in the US. Scotiabank argues that the increase in wages may explain the recent trend in employment (slack erosion), and it may attract self-employed category back into the workforce. It also notes "workers are getting wage gains that are outstripping the rising cost of living." The data will therefore likely be received well at the BOC, and some analysts suggest it may contribute towards a more hawkish stance over the coming months.

* SPX +0.31%, NDX 0.00%, DJI +0.30%. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.28%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +1.04%, Energy: -0.31%, Financials: +0.20%, Health Care: +0.62%, Industrials: +0.32%, Materials: +0.24%, Telecoms: +0.02%, Tech: +0.16%, Utilities: -0.21%.

Following a very rangebound overnight session for the US futures, as European traders sat at their desk, some selling was seen in the ES which consolidated around the 2755 level before pairing back those losses in a gradual climb for most of the session and finishing higher as markets await G7 updates.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple was said to warn suppliers about a 20% decline in iPhone parts order, according to Nikkei, and now expects shipments of 80mln units for the new phones, down from the 100mln unit orders it ordered the previous year. On the earnings front, Broadcom (AVGO) earnings slightly beat expectations on EPS front, and revenues were in line, but guidance on Q3 wireless revenue was weak, which saw the stock lower by 3% and trading at the bottom of the SPX & NDX. Monster Beverages (MNST) traded at the top of the SPX and supported the consumer staples sector on Friday following its AGM, where it stated its US business is showing strong momentum and said there is room to increase prices later this year to offset the higher aluminium costs following tariffs. JP Morgan’s (JPM), Amazon’s (AMZN) and Berkshire’s (BRK.A) candidate to lead their joint healthcare venture stated he would not lead the entity as he is focused on his current CEO position at Geisinger Health System. M&A flow was very light today, however during hours CNBC reported Dialog Semiconductor (DLE GY) is in talks for touch screen maker Synaptics (SYNA), but the initial offer of USD 59/shr was rejected. Elsewhere, CNBC’s Faber reported that Comcast’s (CMCSA) bid for 21st Century Fox (FOXA) is coming on June 13th. Elsewhere, NY Post reported that the legal battle for CBS (CBS) & National Amusements has been set for October 3rd.

* WTI FUTURES (JULY 18) SETTLE USD 0.21 LOWER AT USD 65.74/BBL, BRENT FUTURES (AUGUST 18) SETTLE USD HIGHER AT USD /BBL. Sources reported Russia's Energy Minister Novak and Saudi's Oil Minister Al-Falih will discuss oil output cut deal in Moscow World Cup. Iran's OPEC Governor says its "crazy" and "astonishing" that US President Trump asked Saudi to cover shortfalls caused by Iran nuclear deal decision; adding that oil could reach USD 140/bbl following sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. This US President Trump requesting oil support from Saudi ahead of the Iran nuclear deal decision. OPEC will likely reject the Iranian request for OPEC to discuss US sanctions on Iran at the next meeting, according to sources. Venezuela is also seeking OPEC support like Iran, in the midst of US sanctions, as well as Saudi Arabia reportedly said to increase June output by 100k BPD following sanctions, they already raised output by 100k BPD in May, according to sources. Oil rigs rose for a third week in a row to 862 from 861.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (SEP 2018) UNCHANGED AT 119-19.

Treasuries were pretty much unchanged on Friday as investors have been cautiously awaiting for a G7 outcome and ahead of FOMC and ECB next week. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve though yields were lower by less than c.1bps. Spreads were mixed, 2s10s were wider by c.1bps at settlement.

FX

EUR was a key source for FX markets throughout the week in the wake of Tuesday’s ECB source reports suggesting that next week is a ‘live’ meeting for discussions on the bank’s intentions to curtail their PSPP programme with a potential announcement to be made in July. This helped EUR/USD make a more sustained break above 1.1700 before garnering further support to breach 1.1800 amid a slew of ECB speakers with the most notable interjection coming from ECB’s Praet. BAML highlighted Praet as giving “a generally positive assessment of the 3 criteria he had laid out to assess ‘progress’ (convergence, confidence, resilience)”. Adding that “this is very significant coming from a board member who has always sat decisively on the dovish end of the spectrum”.

For the USD more broadly, the aforementioned EUR move was a key driving force in the greenback’s descent which saw the DXY give up 93.50 to the downside in the middle of the week. Rabobank at the time, showed little concern for the pullback in the USD and stated it was natural given how quickly the greenback had risen over the past few weeks. Towards the back-end of the week the USD nursed losses and saw the DXY head back towards 94.00 amid a tone of general risk aversion with focus now on the G7 summit. Ahead of which, markets are operating with a degree of caution thus far as lingering tensions concerning US tariffs threaten to isolate US President Trump at the G7. This also comes amid Trump’s latest tweet-tirade against the EU and Canada in which the President accused EU & Canada of using massive trade tariffs and trade barriers against US, and warned both nations to remove them or they will be matched.

A busy week for GBP with Brexit back at the helm as Brexit headlines returned with a vengeance. Davis refrained from resigning after forcing UK PM May to ‘fudge’ her backstop proposal be stating that the government ‘expects’ the temporary customs union to cease by the end of 2021. Commentary was mixed on who was the actual victor out of May and Davis but ultimately, the Tory in-fighting did little to appease investor concern or raise expectations that the UK will be able to present the EU with a suitable solution. In terms of the EU response, despite initial optimism from Barnier stating that he is ready to increase the pace of negotiations, the EU negotiator adopted a more cynical tone throughout his speech by raising objections to the UK’s backstop ‘solution’; GBP/USD closes the week out back below 1.3400.

For EM central banks, the CBRT provided some support for the TRY after the central bank unexpectedly hiked its one-week repo rate by 125bps to 17.75%. Capital Economics note that the decision was “a tentative sign that it is shifting its focus away from simply shoring up the lira and towards tackling high and rising inflation. The key now is whether more orthodox policymaking lasts beyond this month’s election. If President Erdogan emerges victorious and renews his calls for lower interest rates, the lira would sell-off and (ironically) strengthen the case for further rate hikes”.

The Brazilian central bank has been active in the FX market this week, upping swaps operations in order to stem the slide in the BRL; initially, its efforts were in vain, and spot FX rose above the 3.80 level it was defending, before the central bank once again intervened at 3.90 (to little avail); however, comments from the central bank’s chief suggesting that the BCB is willing to up their aggression of intervention, as well as an expanded swap programme (adding $20bln through next week, also pledging to meet the market’s demand for dollars through other tools as well, such as spot, as well as credit lines), have helped bring the BRL back beneath 3.80 as we close out the week. Thus far, the central bank has signalled that it has no intention to lift rates, with intervention being the first line of defence. Analysts at ING, however, believes that current monetary policy guidance, which exclusively focusses on inflation, underestimates the need for rate rises. “Should the BRL instability continue, a rate hike of 50-150bp could happen much sooner than expected, but perhaps the BRL would have to cross the 4.00 barrier first for the bank to start considering such drastic measures,” ING believes.

*COMING-UP NEXT WEEK: FOMC: The overwhelming expectation is that the FOMC will lift its Fed Funds Rate target corridor by 25bps on Thursday, for the second time in 2018, to 1.75%-2.00%; money markets are pricing in the hike with a certainty over 90%, and as such, the market may not take its cue from the rate decision itself, but more from the FOMC's view of future hikes. content:

If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

8th June 2018

Earnings

  • Broadcom (AVGO) Q2 EPS USD 4.88 vs.Exp. USD 4.75, revenue USD 5.0bln vs. Exp. USD 5.0bln; announces a quarterly dividend of USD 1.75/shr. Sees Q3 GAAP gross margin 50.75%, forecasts Q3 net revenue USD 5.05bln. (Newswires)
  • Cooper Companies (COO) Q2 EPS USD 2.86 vs.  Exp. USD 2.84, revenue USD 0.631bln vs. Exp. USD 0.627bln. (Newswires)
  • Home Group (HOME) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.31 vs.  Exp. USD 0.27, revenue USD 0.256bln vs. Exp. USD 0.256bln. (Newswires)
  • Stitch Fix (SFIX) Q3 EPS USD 0.09 vs.  Exp. USD 0.03, revenue USD 0.316bln vs. Exp. USD 0.306bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant is said to warn of a 20% drop in new iPhone parts orders. Separately, the co.’s supplier Foxconn posted the fastest monthly increase in sales in around half a year. (Nikkei)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The bank and Morgan Stanley (MS) were left out from the banks' lobbying powerhouse in Washington. Separately, Malaysia may reportedly be asking the US DoJ to make the company return nearly USD 600mln in fees it earned from bonds raised for Malaysia Development Berhad, according to two people familiar with the matter. (WSJ/Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The co. has requested the court to block the departure of a top tax executive moving to Amazon (AMZN). (Newswires)

S&P500

  • CBS (CBS) – The legal battle between the co. and its active shareholder National Amusements has been set for October 3rd at Delaware Chancery Court. (NY Post)
  • Credit card names (AXP, COF, DFS) – The credit card issuers are extending their loan loss reserves more than their credit in preparation for losses. (Newswires)
  • Healthcare names (HNT, AET, MOH, UNH, HUM, WCG, ANTM, CNC, CI) – The US Justice Department is not going to defend some key points of the 'Obamacare' act. (WSJ)
  • Philip Morris (PM) – The co. raised it quarterly dividend by 6.5% to USD 1.14 from USD 1.07. (Newswires)
  • Royal Caribbean (RCL) – The cruise chain is aiming to eliminate plastic straws by the end of 2018. (Newswires)
  • Target (TGT) – The co. is expanding same-day delivery of groceries and drive up pick -up services as part of its Ship service in the Southwest and Midwest. It is to expand the service in more than 135 markets by the end of June and almost 1000 stores will offer the Drive-Up service by holiday. Target Restock to be available to around 75% of the US population. (Newswires)
  • Verizon (VZ) – The co. announced Hans Vestberg is to be new CEO, effective August 1s, he is currently Chief Technology Officer at the co. Separately, an EU regulator urged Yahoo to make changes in privacy following last year data breach investigation. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The co. is looking to introduce Google Home in more markets to compete with Amazon (AMZN). (DigiTimes)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL)/Twitter (TWTR) – A senator has requested information about their partnerships with China. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) –Some fund managers avoid the retail giant as it is leading the US market and the recent volatility combined with the stock’s high valuation make it risky, anticipating a significant decline in its value. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) / JP Morgan (JPM) / Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) – CEO candidate for their healthcare joint venture, David Feinberg, has stated he will not lead the venture as he remains committed to Geisinger Health System. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – Chief Privacy Officer Erin Egan recognised an audience selector error and informed 14mln users. Separately, the social network company is seeking to employ 'news credibility specialists' responsible for creating a list of credible news bodies. (Newswires/Business Insider)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) – The chipmaker has extended its cash offer for NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) to June 15th. (Newswires)
  • Twenty-Century Fox (FOXA)/Disney (DIS) – US regulator reported the two have surgically separated assets over the USD 52.4bln offer made by Disney (DIS). (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Alibaba (BABA) – The Chinese e-commerce giant’s subsidiary, Ant Financial, announced it has entered an agreement with investors for its Series C equity financing, bringing it to a total of USD 14bln. (Newswires)
  • Cree (CREE) – Back Q4 Adj. EPS view USD 0.05 – USD 0.09 vs. Exp. USD 0.08, back Q4 revenue view USD 0.390bln -USD 0.410mln vs. Exp. USD 0.400bln. (Newswires)
  • Enbridge (ENB) – BP complained the Canada’s National Energy Board (NEB) regulator regarding the company’s implementation followed by a reversal of new rules for crude shipping on the Mainline pipeline system. (Newswires)
  • Energizer (ENR)/ Spectrum Brands (SPB) – The two firms are looking to file a merger agreement with the European Commission. (Newswires)
  • Las Vegas Sands (LVS) – The co. raised its share repurchase programme to USD 2.5bln from USD 1.56bln. (Newswires)
  • Lululemon (LULU) – The co is to repurchase 3.3mln shares from Advent International. (Newswires)
  • Lumentum (LITE) – CFO Aaron Tachibana resigned, and Chris Coldren was named interim CFO. (Newswires
  • Rowan Companies (RDC) – The co. was granted a drillship contract by Exxon Mobil (XOM). (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

content:
• Welcomes UK customs paper and it happy that the UK are engaging with the EU by proposing texts. 
  • He adds that UK recognises that its proposals cannot qualify as a backstop as it does not address regulatory alignment
  • He stated that he is ready to increase the pace of negotiations and believes some issues can be resolved ahead of the June 28th summit but there is still work to be done
  • He says a backstop must be active as long as there is no better solution to avoid a hard border

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US President Trump’s Twitter tirade overnight vs. Canada and France has soured the risk tone
  • Equity bourses all negative and safe-havens bid across the board
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, Canadian jobs report and the beginning of the G7 summit

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded with a subdued tone following a lacklustre performance on Wall St, where the major indices finished mixed as tech underperformed and the Nasdaq pulled back from record levels, although the energy sector was underpinned on oil gains. In addition, lingering tensions concerning US tariffs which threatens to isolate US President Trump at the G7, as well as a Trump tweet tirade against EU and Canada, added to the gloom. ASX 200 (-0.2%) traded indecisive as upside in energy and financials were counterbalanced by weakness in miners, while Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was downbeat as participants digested weaker than expected GDP data which printed at a contraction and in-line with the preliminary reading. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.3%) and Hang Seng (-1.8%) were the laggards after PBoC operations resulted to a weekly net liquidity drain of CNY 300bln and with participants cautious in anticipation of the Chinese trade data which turned out to be mostly better than expected, although by then the selling had already taken its toll. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat despite the cautiousness in Japan, while the BoJ’s Rinban operation was also largely ignored with the total amount at a relatively reserved JPY 360bln.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a weekly net drain of CNY 300bln vs. last week's CNY 410bln net injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4003 (Prev. 6.3919)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(May) 24.9B vs. Exp. 33.8B (Prev. 28.8B)

Chinese Imports (USD)(May) Y/Y 26.0% vs. Exp. 18.8% (Prev. 21.5%)

Chinese Exports (USD)(May) Y/Y 12.6% vs. Exp. 11.3% (Prev. 12.9%)

Japanese GDP (Q1 F) Q/Q -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)

Japanese GDP Annualized (Q1 F) Y/Y -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. -0.6%)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May reaffirms that she ‘expects’ to have a state customs plan in place by December 2021 at the latest, while she also says UK is working to ensure EU response to US tariffs is proportionate and adheres to WTO regulations. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said that the backstop proposal is a "step forward". (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Russian President Putin has asked Austrian leader to set up a summit with US President Trump. (WSJ)

EQUITIES

European bourses are all in the red (Euro stoxx 50 -0.86%) as markets exude a risk off tone before the G7 summit later today. This comes after US President Trump struck a confrontational tone vs. Canada and France overnight on Twitter.

The FTSE MIB is currently the underperformer, with this risk-off tone exacerbated by internal political tensions hitting Italian assets, currently down 1.7%.

The materials sector (+1.1%) is the current underperformer on softer base metals.

Significant stock specific news comes from BT Group (+0.3%), with CEO Gavin Patterson announcing his resignation, with Severn Trent’s (-1.1%) Garfield touted as the successor.

A Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank merger was rebuked by Deutsche Bank shareholders.

Novo Nordisk have dropped their long-term financial targets, and will be cutting 3,000 jobs, according to sources. The Scandinavian company is currently down 3.4%.

Apple (AAPL) is said to warn of a 20% drop in new IPhone parts orders, as according to Nikkei

FX

USD has staged a modest recovery in early European trade with the DXY back above 93.50 ahead of the G7 summit. Markets are operating with a degree of caution thus far as lingering tensions concerning US tariffs threatens to isolate US President Trump at the G7. This also comes amid Trump’s latest tweet-tirade against the EU and Canada in which the President accused EU & Canada of using massive trade tariffs and trade barriers against US, and warned both nations to remove them or they will be matched.

Subsequently, the broad flight to quality has seen some support for USD and out-muscling of it’s major counterparts with the exception of JPY. USD/JPY is back below 109.50 and its 10DMA at 109.45 with the Japanese currency being guided more by the broader risk-tone rather than weaker than expected GDP data which printed at a contraction and in-line with the preliminary reading.

EUR/USD has given back some of its recent gains and is back below 1.1800 as part of a broader USD move with the ECB now in their blackout period. In terms of market expectations, consensus looks for around a 33% chance of Draghi announcing an end-date for the Bank’s purchases next week with almost 50% seeing July as a more opportune time. Note, this morning saw yet further disappointing data from the Eurozone with German industrial output falling short of expectations. 

GBP has stabilised in early European trade after yesterday’s Brexit-related selling pressure. Tory in-fighting will likely dominate proceedings this side of the channel with UK Foreign Minister Johnson critical of PM May’s approach to Brexit and instead recommended taking a more ‘Trump-like’ style in negotiations. Focus now turns towards the EU response with EU chief negotiator Barnier due to offer his response to May’s proposal yesterday. Note, at the time of publication Barnier tweeted yesterday “I welcome publication of #UK proposal on customs aspects of IE/NI backstop. We will examine it with 3 questions: is it a workable solution to avoid a hard border? Does it respect the integrity of the SM/CU? Is it an all-weather backstop?”

AUD has also fallen victim to the firmer USD with overnight trade data from China unable to prop up the currency. As a reminder, Chinese trade data saw a smaller than anticipated surplus but firm export/import components suggests that recent trade rhetoric from the US has been unable to make a noteworthy impact on data thusfar. From a technical perspective, the next key level to the downside for AUD/USD is at 0.7576 which marks the 38.2% fib of the move from 0.7413 (May 11th low) to 0.7677 (6-week high printed this Wednesday).

FIXED INCOME

Fixed income markets have succumbed to the broader risk tone with supported provided to paper throughout the session. Fixed income markets saw a brief surge mid-morning with a large block buyer of 24k in the US 10yr at 119.27 coinciding with the move which also saw Bunds spike through 161.00 to the upside; a level which has since been given up. Elsewhere in Europe, BTPs have once again diverged from their peers and have extended the losses seen late yesterday which some have attributed to yesterday’s slip in Brazilian assets and leverage funds closing out positions following last week’s volatility; but ultimately, any decisive reason remains unclear. In UK markets, Gilts have followed the trend set by USTs and Bunds with gains capped by 122.00 and trends resistance around 122.17; Barnier’s presser at 1300BST the next source of focus for domestic paper.

COMMODITIES

Oil is erasing some of the gains seen on Thursday trade, with both WTI and Brent down 0.5%. The fossil fuel is seeing some pressure from a rising USD, as well as a general risk off mood ahead of the G7 summit.

In the metals scope, Gold is up on the day as a result of this risk-off tone, with the yellow metal up 0.15%.

Copper has retreated for the first time in 6 sessions after hitting 4 ½ year highs following supply disruptions, with profit taking pressuring the metal down 1% on the day.

Steel has slipped from 6 month highs, but these losses are being capped by ongoing supply concerns in China, the metal is currently down 1%.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

8th June 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded with a subdued tone following a lacklustre performance on Wall St, where the major indices finished mixed as tech underperformed and the Nasdaq pulled back from record levels, although the energy sector was underpinned on oil gains. In addition, lingering tensions concerning US tariffs which threatens to isolate US President Trump at the G7, as well as a Trump tweet tirade against EU and Canada, added to the gloom. ASX 200 (Unch.) traded indecisive as upside in energy and financials were counterbalanced by weakness in miners, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) was downbeat as participants digested weaker than expected GDP data which printed at a contraction and in-line with the preliminary reading. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.3%) and Hang Seng (-1.3%) were the laggards after PBoC operations resulted to a weekly net liquidity drain of CNY 300bln and with participants cautious in anticipation of the Chinese trade data which turned out to be mostly better than expected, although by then the selling had already taken its toll. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat despite the cautiousness in Japan, while the BoJ’s Rinban operation was also largely ignored with the total amount at a relatively reserved JPY 360bln.

FTSE

RBS (RBS LN) – The CEO of the bank is very confident RBS will pass stress tests this year. Also, CEO says they would like to purchase shares back from the UK government if possible and states their first dividend would be modest.  (Newswires)

Whitbread (WTB LN) – the co. has said it is open to selling its Costa Coffee or Premier Inn units; abandoning plans to spin-off the coffee chain. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT LN) - Geordie Greig has been named as the new Editor of the Daily Mail. (Newswires)

Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN) -  Lloyds Banking group is to sell 97.7mln shares of the co. (FT)

TSB (TSB LN) - UK Treasury Committee of Lawmakers has ‘Lost confidence’ in CEO of TSB bank, Paul Pester. (Newswires)

Marks & Spencer (MKS LN) – Directors of the co. will not receive a bonus this year after the second straight annual fall in profits. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

AUTOTRADER (AUTO LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

RANDGOLD RESOURCES (RRS LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM ENUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

DAX

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 8th June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks traded with a subdued tone following a lacklustre performance on Wall St. DXY has languished below the 93.50 level
  • Trump launched a tweet-tirade against EU and Canada ahead of the G7, in which Trump accused EU & Canada of using massive trade tariffs and trade barriers against US
  • Looking ahead, highlights including the Canadian jobs report and the beginning of the G7 summit

 

ASIA

Asian stocks traded with a subdued tone following a lacklustre performance on Wall St, where the major indices finished mixed as tech underperformed and the Nasdaq pulled back from record levels, although the energy sector was underpinned on oil gains. In addition, lingering tensions concerning US tariffs which threatens to isolate US President Trump at the G7, as well as a Trump tweet tirade against EU and Canada, added to the gloom. ASX 200 (Unch.) traded indecisive as upside in energy and financials were counterbalanced by weakness in miners, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) was downbeat as participants digested weaker than expected GDP data which printed at a contraction and in-line with the preliminary reading. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.3%) and Hang Seng (-1.3%) were the laggards after PBoC operations resulted to a weekly net liquidity drain of CNY 300bln and with participants cautious in anticipation of the Chinese trade data which turned out to be mostly better than expected, although by then the selling had already taken its toll. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat despite the cautiousness in Japan, while the BoJ’s Rinban operation was also largely ignored with the total amount at a relatively reserved JPY 360bln.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a weekly net drain of CNY 300bln vs. last week's CNY 410bln net injection. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4003 (Prev. 6.3919)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(May) 156.5B vs. Exp. 243.0B (Prev. 182.8B)
Chinese Exports (CNY)(May) Y/Y 3.2% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 3.7%)
Chinese Imports (CNY)(May) Y/Y 15.6% vs. Exp. 9.4% (Prev. 11.6%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(May) 24.9B vs. Exp. 33.8B (Prev. 28.8B)

Chinese Imports (USD)(May) Y/Y 26.0% vs. Exp. 18.8% (Prev. 21.5%)

Chinese Exports (USD)(May) Y/Y 12.6% vs. Exp. 11.3% (Prev. 12.9%)

Japanese GDP (Q1 F) Q/Q -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)
Japanese GDP Annualized (Q1 F) Y/Y -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. -0.6%)


UK/EU

UK PM May reaffirms that she ‘expects’ to have a state customs plan in place by December 2021 at the latest, while she also says UK is working to ensure EU response to US tariffs is proportionate and adheres to WTO regulations. (Newswires)

UK Foreign Minister Johnson criticised UK PM May’s Brexit Plan and stated that Britain should adopt an approach similar to that of US President Trump. (Newswires)

UK’s CBI has warned that Britain risks being left in the economic “slow lane” compared with other developed nations amid the impact of Brexit unless the government and business step up efforts to lift investment and productivity. (Times)

US President Trump may not hold formal discussions with UK PM May at the G7 summit. (Telegraph)

SNB's Jordan said the current economic situation is very good and that it is very unlikely they will leave the Eurozone. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the USD was flat with the DXY languishing below the 93.50 level amid concerns Trump policies may isolate the US. This was not helped by Trump’s tweet-tirade against EU and Canada ahead of the G7, in which Trump accused EU & Canada of using massive trade tariffs and trade barriers against US, and warned both nations to remove them or they will be matched. The rest of major currencies lacked drivers with EUR/USD stuck around 1.1800 and with GBP/USD virtually unchanged throughout the entire session. Elsewhere, USD/JPY’s attempts to nurse losses were thwarted by the cautious risk tone and AUD remained pressured from the prior day’s disappointing Australian trade data.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were quiet overnight in which WTI crude futures were marginally higher and just about reclaimed the USD 66.00/bbl level, after the prior day’s rebound amid ongoing Venezuelan supply concerns. Elsewhere, gold conformed to the uneventful tone seen across the commodities complex and copper also languished due to the aversion for risk in the region.


GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said summit with North Korea is ready to go, while he also commented that US could sign an agreement with Kim during the summit and that the US would certainly like to see normalisation of ties with North Korea. However, US President Trump also stated he would be willing to walk away from talks with North Korea, but that he does not want this to be the case and that if talks go well he will invite Kim Jong Un to the US. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said North Korea confirmed to the US its willingness to denuclearise but also commented that North Korea's programmes threaten the US. (Newswires)
 

Satellite images suggested China removed or hid its missile systems from disputed South China Sea island, although its Foreign Ministry said it will not bow to threats of US ramping up patrols. (Newswires)
 

Russian President Putin has asked Austrian leader to set up a summit with US President Trump. (WSJ)


US

Treasuries began to rise as the North America session got underway -- contrary to the price action in Bunds (which edged lower over as European political risks abate, and the ECB prepares to signal policy normalisation next week) whose price action Treasuries have tended to track in early trade -- on the back of increasing tensions between the US and its major trade partners, ahead of the G7 summit. The Tplex got more of an aggressive bid in afternoon trade, after US President Trump once again stipulated that NK must denuclearise fully in order for any peace deal to be reached, while contentious rhetoric between trade partners continued to aid the upside, seeing Treasury futures move higher. There was a further boost to the Tplex in afternoon trade: reportedly fat fingers pushed large buy orders through in the 10yr space, eventually triggering stops, which saw yields spike lower, before paring back; the EM complex was under pressure at the time, and some suggest that CTA/momentum accounts accelerated selling of EMFX against the USD, selling equities in general (nudging the VIX higher), ultimately supporting the Treasury bid. The yield curve bull-flattened on Thursday with shorter dated yields lower by c.4bps and longer dated yields lower by c.6bps; 2s30s and 2s20s were narrower by c.2bps at settlement. US 10YR T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled 10 ticks higher at 119-90.

US President Trump tweeted EU & Canada doesn't inform public that for years they have used massive trade tariffs and non-monetary trade barriers against US, which is unfair to US farmers, workers & companies, while he warned them to take down their tariffs & barriers or the US will match them. (Twitter)

White House stated that US President Trump is to leave the G-7 earlier than had previously scheduled. (Newswires)

US House voted 210-206 to pass the rescission bill to cut around USD 15bln in previously approved spending. (Newswires)

In addition, lingering tensions concerning US tariffs on its allies, threatens to isolate US President Trump at the G7 and adds to the current gloom. ASX 200 (-0.1%) trades indecisive as upside in energy and financials are counterbalanced by weakness in miners, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) is also choppy with participants digesting weaker than expected GDP data which printed at a contraction and in-line with the preliminary reading. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) and Hang Seng (-0.9%) are the laggards after PBoC operations resulted to a weekly net liquidity drain of CNY 300bln and with participants also cautious ahead of the Chinese trade data.

In FX markets, the USD is flat with the DXY languishing below the 93.50 level amid concerns Trump policies may isolate the US. This was not helped by Trump’s tweet-tirade against EU and Canada ahead of the G7, in which Trump accused EU & Canada of using massive trade tariffs and trade barriers against US, and also warned both nations to remove them or they will be matched. Elsewhere, the rest of major currencies lacked drivers with EUR/USD stuck around 1.1800 and with GBP/USD virtually unchanged, while USD/JPY’s attempts to nurse losses have been hampered by the cautious risk tone and AUD continues to lack vitality following the prior day’s disappointing trade data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat amid the somewhat indecisive picture in Japan and with the BoJ’s Rinban operation largely ignored with the total amount at a relatively reserved JPY 360bln.
